"FUNNIES" CREATED BY GREEKS
SAYS DR. DAVID M. ROBINSON

Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of archaeology, and officer and
member of many- classical societies
and organizations, came into national prominence on December 31,
when he stated in a lecture before the Archaelogical Institute of
America, in session at Haverford
College, that the art of caricature
was not modern, but that it was
noticeable in the work of the
Greeks. Vases found in recent excavations brought the subject of a
hitherto unsuspected Greek art of
caricature to the fore. Dr. Robinson's speech was reported by the
Associated Press throughout the
country.
The ancients had "funnies," he
said in his lecture, for one vase
picture he told about was a comical
scene of Circe handing a goblet of
wine to Ulysses. This picture, and
one of Perseus cutting off the head
of the Gorgon Medusa, with another showing pigmies battling with
cranes, were created with humorous
ideas in the minds of the artists,
and the inference was drawn that
caricature was not the creation of
modern newspaper artists, but probably the invention of early Greek
vase decorators.
Dr. Robinson returned to the
University after the meeting of the
archaeologists at Haverford, much
amused that his statement had attracted such attention.

was born at Summit Point, Jefferson County, W. Va., just over the
Virginia line, in 1878. His ancestors, an old Scotch family, had resided in Virginia since early anteRevolutionary days.
Mr. Thomson's father is Dr. A.
Pembroke Thomson, who was the
pioneer fruit grower of the Valley
of Virginia. Years ago Dr. Thomson turned his fields of wheat into
peach orchards, and it made him
wealthy.
Mr. Thomson graduated with a
degree of A. B. at Johns Hopkins
University in 1897, when only nineteen years old. His college career
was signalized by his first journalistic experience when he founded
and edited the first successful college paper at the University—THE
NEWS-LETTER. Mr. Thomson afterward studied law for a short
time and in 1898 he went to Washington and took up reportorial work
on the Washington Post, later organizing the Interview Syndicate
and doing special work in the
Washington bureaus of the New
York papers.
After a few years' work in
Washington he borrowed $1,500
from his father, went to Norfolk,
Va., and bought an obscure fourpage sheet called the Dispatch.
That section of Virginia at the time
was controlled by a powerful political machine. As soon as Mr.
Thomson got his bearings, he began bombarding political corruption. From that day the Dispatch
began to grow. Its circulation
leaped from a few hundred to thousands. His editorials and his expose of corrupt political life fanned
to a flame a revolt against "machine" politics and a "Good Government" party was born and placed
in power. The Dispatch grew from
a small, four-page newspaper to a
twelve and sixteen page sheet, with
25,000 circulation, and Mr. Thomson, its directing genius, became
one of the most hated as well as
best beloved men of Norfolk.
Like all ambitious men, Mr.
Thomson began looking for larger
fields. He received an offer of
$115,000 for the Dispatch, in which
he had made an original investment
of only $1,500 six years before.
After consulting with his partner,
Peter Wright, a shrewd business
man, he accepted this offer and
went to New Orleans and bought
the Item, which he has developed
into one of the leading daily papers
of the South.

MAY PLAY FOOTBALL NO MORE

Frankie Bowers, star quarterback
of the 1913 football team, who has
been suffering this fall from an
acute attack of typhoid fever. returned to the University during

Political Economy Seminary during
the next two terms.
Bowers reported for football
practice the first day of the season
this year, but the next day typhoid
developed with complications. At
one time it was feared that pneumonia had set in, but fortunately

off. The ribs which he broke in
the Carlisle game last year caused
a great deal of trouble, and for
this reason his doctors have forbidden him to play football again.

severe blow to the team, as his
Clever generalship and fast openfield running did much to bring
the 1913 team into winning form.

THE NURTURE OF OUR YOUTH
An Essay By Dr. H.E.Greene, Collegiate
Professor of English, on Undergraduate Reading.

THE NEWS-LETTER reprints below part of Dr. Herbert E. Greene's
recent article in the Alumni Magazine on "The Nurture of Our
Youth." We regret that the length
of the essay requires many omissions which spoil the unity and effect of the original article:
"About four years ago I had a
conversation with the mother of a
freshman in one of our large universities. His entire course of
study she was willing to take for
granted, with the exception of one
subject; but in regard to this she
showed deep concern. Will my son
have an opportunity to study bookkeeping?' she asked. 'After he
graduates from college he is going
into business; and it will be very
important for him to know bookkeeping.' Nothing that I could say
availed in any way to arouse an
interest in other studies. A few
months ago I had another conversation with this lady, whom I had
not seen during the interval. Her
son was shortly to graduate from
college. He had not studied bookkeeping, but to her great gratification he had become deeply
interested in English literature.
'When he went to college,' she said,
'he cared little for reading; now
he is very fond of it.' She was
pleased indeed that while he was in
college he had acquired one of the
-tastes of a cultivated man, and had
gained a never-failing resource for
the busy years that were before
him. Her son has gone into business, and has already won promotion; but he has had no occasion
thus far to do bookkeeping.
"There is much truth in the saying that if a man does not read
widely before he reaches the age of
twenty-five, it is not probable that
he will ever do so. This young man
had acquired before that age the
habit of reading. It is in the home
that this habit is most readily and
most naturally acquired. If the
novels of Scott and Dickens, the
poems of Tennyson and Longfellow
are easy of access, and if a boy sees
that the reading of his parents is
not confined to the daily paper and
the magazine, in most cases—not
in all—he will, almost without
knowing it, acquire at home the
habit of reading.
"The editors of the Alumni Magazine have asked me to discuss the
subject of student reading in college. Every entering class may be
divided broadly into two sections,
one section made up of students
who are already readers, the other
of those who are indifferent to good
reading. For those who have already acquired the habit of reading, the instructor can best serve
as a guide and adviser who may
save them from misdirected effort
and loss of time; for the indifferent
he must try to open their eyes to

Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of archaeology, and officer and
member of many- classical societies
and organizations, came into national prominence on December 31,
when he stated in a lecture before the Archaelogical Institute of
America, in session at Haverford
College, that the art of caricature
was not modern, but that it was
noticeable in the work of the
Greeks. Vases found in recent excavations brought the subject of a
hitherto unsuspected Greek art of
caricature to the fore. Dr. Robinson's speech was reported by the
Associated Press throughout the
country.
The ancients had "funnies," he
said in his lecture, for one vase
picture he told about was a comical
scene of Circe handing a goblet of
wine to Ulysses. This picture, and
one of Perseus cutting off the head
of the Gorgon Medusa, with another showing pigmies battling with
cranes, were created with humorous
ideas in the minds of the artists,
and the inference was drawn that
caricature was not the creation of
modern newspaper artists, but probably the invention of early Greek
vase decorators.
Dr. Robinson returned to the
University after the meeting of the
archaeologists at Haverford, much
amused that his statement had attracted such attention.

THE NURTURE OF OUR YOUTH
An Essay By Dr. H.E.Greene, Collegiate
Professor of English, on Undergraduate Reading.

THE NEWS-LETTER reprints below part of Dr. Herbert E. Greene's
recent article in the Alumni Magazine on "The Nurture of Our
Youth." We regret that the length
of the essay requires many omissions which spoil the unity and effect of the original article:
"About four years ago I had a
conversation with the mother of a
freshman in one of our large universities. His entire course of
study she was willing to take for
granted, with the exception of one
subject; but in regard to this she
showed deep concern. Will my son
have an opportunity to study bookkeeping?' she asked. 'After he
graduates from college he is going
into business; and it will be very
important for him to know bookkeeping.' Nothing that I could say
availed in any way to arouse an
interest in other studies. A few
months ago I had another conversation with this lady, whom I had
not seen during the interval. Her
son was shortly to graduate from
college. He had not studied bookkeeping, but to her great gratification he had become deeply
interested in English literature.
'When he went to college,' she said,
'he cared little for reading; now
he is very fond of it.' She was
pleased indeed that while he was in
college he had acquired one of the
-tastes of a cultivated man, and had
gained a never-failing resource for
the busy years that were before
him. Her son has gone into business, and has already won promotion; but he has had no occasion
thus far to do bookkeeping.
"There is much truth in the saying that if a man does not read
widely before he reaches the age of
twenty-five, it is not probable that
he will ever do so. This young man
had acquired before that age the
habit of reading. It is in the home
that this habit is most readily and
most naturally acquired. If the
novels of Scott and Dickens, the
poems of Tennyson and Longfellow
are easy of access, and if a boy sees
that the reading of his parents is
not confined to the daily paper and
the magazine, in most cases—not
in all—he will, almost without
knowing it, acquire at home the
habit of reading.
"The editors of the Alumni Magazine have asked me to discuss the
subject of student reading in college. Every entering class may be
divided broadly into two sections,
one section made up of students
who are already readers, the other
of those who are indifferent to good
reading. For those who have already acquired the habit of reading, the instructor can best serve
as a guide and adviser who may
save them from misdirected effort
and loss of time; for the indifferent
he must try to open their eyes to

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 4, 1915.

the interest and attractiveness of
good reading—an undertaking that
to some will appear to be simple and
easy, to others perplexing and difficult. As a matter of fact, the success with which one meets is most
gratifying.
"The same class of freshmen or
of sophomores may contain students
who have read all of the plays of
Shakespeare, perhaps plays by other
Elizabethan dramatists, and students who have never read one of
the plays of Shakespeare; those
who are fairly well acquainted with
the course of English poetry from
Spenser to Swinburne, and who
have themselves practiced the art
of verse, and those to whom poetry
makes little or no appeal; some who
are familiar with the English novel
from Samuel Richardson to George
Meredith, and some who have never
read one of the novels of Sir Walter
Scott. * * *
"Students of various degrees of
attainment and of interest are taught
together in the introductory course
in English literature. Notwithstanding certain difficulties which
will readily occur to the reader,
it is better so, for the well-read
and interested student is a help and
a stimulus both to the instructor
and to the indifferent student;
moreover, there is so much that is
new, both in content and in point
of view, that the best-read students
are the greatest gainers. He who
brings most carries away most. It
is in the elective courses, however,
that the natural readers congregate;
these and a few conscientious students who wish to improve the opportunities to make up for deficiencies. * * *
"It is the voluntary continuation
and extension of this practice of
private reading, not the reading
done in courses, that I am to discuss. How far does the habit of
reading good literature extend
among our students? If one may
judge by the questions that are
frequently asked about the reading
and the purchase of books, one may
safely infer not only that a considerable number of our students read
